S5.6.footnotes: Benchmark: To evaluate the proposed PLoRA, we perform our experiments on two well-known datasets: CIFAR-100Â [23] and TinyImageNetÂ [24]. Following the protocols proposed inÂ [28], we split 10 incremental stages and only the data of the current stage is available. Besides, to challenge our method, the local dataset of each client is followed by two kinds of non-iid settings: quantity-based label imbalance and distribution-based label imbalanceÂ [25], and we also explore the performance under different degrees of non-iid.Comparison: We compare our method with exisiting FCIL methods: TARGETÂ [59] GLFCÂ [7], LGAÂ [8] and FedETÂ [28]. we also adopt several CIL methodsÂ [22, 27, 41, 52] in FCIL setting and explore their performance in different non-iid settings and degrees of data heterogeneity. Besides, FedET and Fed-CPrompt only conduct experiments using supervised pre-training weights on CIFAR-100. Considering privacy issues, we also evaluate the performance of our method on self-supervised pre-training weights.Implementation: In the selection of pre-training models, we are inspired byÂ [32, 58] and consider both supervised pre-trained weights (ImageNet-21K) and self-supervised pre-trained weights (DinoÂ [5]) for ViT-B/16Â [9]. The LoRA module is inserted in the first 5 blocks. We train our models using AdamÂ [20] with a batch size of 64 and followed byÂ [58], we adopt different learning rates for prototypes layer of 2â€‹eâˆ’32superscriptğ‘’32e^{-3} and LoRA parameters of 1â€‹eâˆ’51superscriptğ‘’51e^{-5} on CIFAR-100, and 5â€‹eâˆ’35superscriptğ‘’35e^{-3}/Â 5â€‹eâˆ’65superscriptğ‘’65e^{-6} on TinyImageNet. Moreover, cosine annealing is also used in training processes. The hyper-parameters Î»=0.001ğœ†0.001\lambda=0.001, Î³=5ğ›¾5\gamma=5 and Î·=0.2ğœ‚0.2\eta=0.2. We initialize 10 local clients to train and upload the parameters at each communication round. The local training epoch is 5 and the communication round is 20.Results are shown in TablesÂ 5,Â 5.1,Â 3. We evaluate methods using ANâ€‹(â†‘)subscriptğ´ğ‘â†‘A_{N}~{}(\uparrow) and AvgÂ (â†‘)â†‘(\uparrow), where ANsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{N} is the accuracy of all seen classes in the final task and Avg. is computed as the average accuracy of all tasks. We obverse that our method significantly outperforms other comparison methods and demonstrates strong robustness across different non-IID settings. Take the result on CIFAR-100 for example, when the data partition of quantity-based label imbalance is Î±=6ğ›¼6\alpha=6, our method outperforms the best ViT-based FCIL methods FedET by 13.2% (ANsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{N}) and well-known CIL method L2P in FL setting by 6.4% with supervised pre-trained weight. In the distribution-based label imbalance setting, our method outperforms L2P+FL by 1.9% with the data partition of Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5. Furthermore, when the degree of the non-iid setting is high (low partition in Table), existing FCIL methods fail to maintain their performance stability and even experience a significant decline. GLFC drops by 45.6% and LGA drops by 53.1% when the partition changed from Î±=6ğ›¼6\alpha=6 to Î±=2ğ›¼2\alpha=2 in quantity-based label imbalance. L2P+FL surprisingly shows considerable robustness, but still drops by 9.4% and 8.0% when the data portion changed from Î±=6ğ›¼6\alpha=6 to Î±=2ğ›¼2\alpha=2 and Î²=0.5ğ›½0.5\beta=0.5 to Î²=0.05ğ›½0.05\beta=0.05. In contrast, our method only drops by 6% and 1.5% respectively, which illustrates that our PLoRA can maintain good performance even under high data heterogeneity.Considering data privacy issues, we argue that using supervised pre-trained weights (e.g., ImageNet-21k) in FCIL requires careful consideration because there will be an overlap between the classes seen in pre-training and the test dataset, which conflicts with the decentralization idea of FL. An alternative way is to utilize a self-supervised pre-trained model to provide diverse and transferable representation. Therefore, we compare the performance of our method and L2P+FL with self-supervised pre-trained weights (Dino), and the results show that the performance of L2P+FL is greatly affected by the pre-trained model. Take the experiments on CIFAR-100 as an example, L2P+FL drops by an average of 34.2% and 28.2% in the two settings respectively, while our method only drops by 8.0% and 6.6%. On TinyImageNet, the performance gap between L2P+FL and our method is even larger. In conclusion, the proposed PLoRA can effectively cope with FCIL issues while protecting data privacy and shows robustness compared to other methods under different non-IID settings and high data heterogeneity.Analysis of Prototype Re-weight: The core idea of our proposed prototype re-weight module is to aggregate prototypes in a manner that closely resembles the true data distribution among clients without disclosing local data information. As shown in Fig.Â 3, the weights calculated through re-weight module align with the distribution of data among different clients. Hence, the global prototypes effectively retain all learned prototype information. In contrast, other methods typically use direct averaging for the classification layer, leading to the fusion of a considerable amount of irrelevant information in the classifier when the data heterogeneity is high, consequently causing classifier bias.TableÂ 4 shows the results of our method in removing knowledge distillationÂ (KD) and prototype re-weightÂ (PR) respectively. We observe that without PR, the model fails to resolve the classifier bias caused by data heterogeneity, so the metrics ANsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{N} and Avg drop significantly. Upon removing KD, although there is an improvement in accuracy, the average forgetting FNsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{N} notably increases, indicating that the model suffered from severe catastrophic forgetting. Therefore, by combining both, our model can effectively address both the data heterogeneity and catastrophic forgetting issues in FCIL.We further compare the communication costs with other methods. As the backbone of the model is frozen during training, only the trainable LoRA module and the local prototypes, as well as the class average feature of current task are uploaded to the global server. As shown in TableÂ 5, our method has the lowest total communication cost at each communication round, which demonstrates that our model can achieve better performance with the lowest communication cost. Moreover, we investigate the model performance as the number of clients increases. As depicted in FigureÂ 4, the modelâ€™s performance declines as the number of clients increases. We believe that under the same non-IID setting, enlarging the number of clients further exacerbates the heterogeneity among clients, consequently impacting the modelâ€™s performance.In this paper, we proposed a simple and effective method of Prototype and Low-Rank AdaptionÂ (PLoRA) for FCIL. We first investigate and highlight that the choice of model architecture and classifier bias are the common ground in addressing CIL and FL. Therefore, we utilize LoRA to fine-tune the pre-trained model for sequential tasks. Unlike other Transformer-based approaches, our method does not rely on module similarity selection mechanisms but is optimized in an end-to-end fashion. To better deal with classifier bias, we adopt prototype learning and utilize heuristic information between prototypes and features to perform weighted aggregation of global prototypes. Experimental results show that our method achieves state-of-the-art results on standard datasets and maintains robustness under different non-IID degrees.

Considering data privacy issues, we argue that using supervised pre-trained weights (

, ImageNet-21k) in FCIL requires careful consideration because there will be an overlap between the classes seen in pre-training and the test dataset, which conflicts with the decentralization idea of FL. An alternative way is to utilize a self-supervised pre-trained model to provide diverse and transferable representation. Therefore, we compare the performance of our method and L2P+FL with self-supervised pre-trained weights (Dino), and the results show that the performance of L2P+FL is greatly affected by the pre-trained model. . On TinyImageNet, the performance gap between L2P+FL and our method is even larger. In conclusion, the proposed PLoRA can effectively cope with FCIL issues while protecting data privacy and shows robustness compared to other methods under different non-IID settings and high data heterogeneity.

The core idea of our proposed prototype re-weight module is to aggregate prototypes in a manner that closely resembles the true data distribution among clients without disclosing local data information. As shown in Fig.Â

, the weights calculated through re-weight module align with the distribution of data among different clients. Hence, the global prototypes effectively retain all learned prototype information. In contrast, other methods typically use direct averaging for the classification layer, leading to the fusion of a considerable amount of irrelevant information in the classifier when the data heterogeneity is high, consequently causing classifier bias.

references: TableÂ 4 shows the results of our method in removing knowledge distillationÂ (KD) and prototype re-weightÂ (PR) respectively. We observe that without PR, the model fails to resolve the classifier bias caused by data heterogeneity, so the metrics ANsubscriptğ´ğ‘A_{N} and Avg drop significantly. Upon removing KD, although there is an improvement in accuracy, the average forgetting FNsubscriptğ¹ğ‘F_{N} notably increases, indicating that the model suffered from severe catastrophic forgetting. references: We further compare the communication costs with other methods. As the backbone of the model is frozen during training, only the trainable LoRA module and the local prototypes, as well as the class average feature of current task are uploaded to the global server. As shown in TableÂ 5, our method has the lowest total communication cost at each communication round, which demonstrates that our model can achieve better performance with the lowest communication cost. Moreover, we investigate the model performance as the number of clients increases. As depicted in FigureÂ 4, the modelâ€™s performance declines as the number of clients increases. We believe that under the same non-IID setting, enlarging the number of clients further exacerbates the heterogeneity among clients, consequently impacting the modelâ€™s performance.
